title: Designated Heritage Assets Service Schema
description: Policy-as-code schema defining the legislative framework, consent processes, and service delivery for designated heritage assets including listed buildings, conservation areas, and related heritage consents under the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, NPPF Chapter 16, and Historic England guidance.

primaryLegislation.statute: Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990
primaryLegislation.jurisdictionScope: England (Wales repealed by Historic Environment (Wales) Act 2023)

keyProvisions.title: Duty to compile lists of buildings of special architectural or historic interest
keyProvisions.summary: Secretary of State duty to compile or approve lists of buildings of special architectural or historic interest. Historic England compiles lists; Secretary of State responsible for listing decisions.
criticalPrinciples: Buildings included if of special architectural or historic interest
Listing considers desirability of preserving features fixed to building or within curtilage
For time being, 'listed building' means building included in compiled/approved list

keyProvisions.title: Restriction on works affecting listed buildings
keyProvisions.summary: Core prohibition on unauthorised works to listed buildings
keyProvisions.statutoryText: Subject to the following provisions of this Act, no person shall execute or cause to be executed any works for the demolition of a listed building or for its alteration or extension in any manner which would affect its character as a building of special architectural or historic interest, unless the works are authorised.
criticalPrinciples: Prohibition applies to demolition, alteration, or extension
Trigger: works must affect character as building of special interest
Criminal offence if unauthorised works carried out
Authorization obtained through listed building consent process

penaltiesForBreach.enforcementPowers: Local planning authority may require reversal of unauthorized works

keyProvisions.title: Grant or refusal of listed building consent
keyProvisions.summary: Duty of local planning authority in determining listed building consent applications
criticalPrinciples: LPA must have special regard to desirability of preserving building or its setting
Must consider preserving features of special architectural or historic interest
Applies to any features fixed to building or within curtilage

keyProvisions.title: General duty as respects listed buildings in exercise of planning functions
keyProvisions.summary: Statutory duty applying to planning permission decisions affecting listed buildings
keyProvisions.statutoryText: In considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority or, as the case may be, the Secretary of State shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.
criticalPrinciples: Applies to planning permission (separate from LBC)
Statutory duty to have 'special regard'
Covers building, setting, and special features
Case law: requires 'considerable importance and weight' (Barnwell Manor)

keyProvisions.title: General duty as respects conservation areas
keyProvisions.summary: Statutory duty in exercise of planning functions affecting conservation areas
keyProvisions.statutoryText: Special attention shall be paid to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character or appearance of [conservation] areas.
criticalPrinciples: Applies to conservation areas designated by local planning authority
Duty to preserve or enhance character or appearance
Special attention must be paid

nationalPolicy.chapter: Chapter 16: Conserving and enhancing the historic environment

keyParagraphs.policyText: Heritage assets range from sites and buildings of local historic value to those of the highest significance, such as World Heritage Sites which are internationally recognised to be of Outstanding Universal Value. These assets are an irreplaceable resource, and should be conserved in a manner appropriate to their significance, so that they can be enjoyed for their contribution to the quality of life of existing and future generations.
criticalConcepts: Contribution to quality of life for present and future generations

requirements: Plans must set out positive strategy for conservation and enjoyment
Include heritage assets most at risk
Consider desirability of sustaining and enhancing significance
Recognize wider social, cultural, economic and environmental benefits
Promote new development making positive contribution to local character
LPAs must maintain or have access to HER
Must contain up-to-date evidence about historic environment
Used to assess significance of heritage assets
Used to predict likelihood of discovering unidentified heritage assets
Applicant must describe significance of affected heritage assets
Include contribution made by setting
Level of detail proportionate to importance
Minimum: consult HER, assess using appropriate expertise
Archaeological interest: desk-based assessment and field evaluation where necessary
LPA must identify and assess particular significance
Take account of available evidence and expertise
Consider when determining impact on heritage asset
Avoid or minimise conflict between conservation and proposal

keyParagraphs.policyText: When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.
criticalPrinciples: Great weight to conservation in all cases
More important asset = greater weight
Applies regardless of level of harm
Scale: Grade II < Grade II* < Grade I < Scheduled Monument/World Heritage Site

keyParagraphs.policyText: Any harm to, or loss of, the significance of a designated heritage asset (from its alteration or destruction, or from development within its setting), should require clear and convincing justification.

tieredApproach.highestSignificance: Substantial harm/loss should be wholly exceptional (scheduled monuments, protected wrecks, registered battlefields, Grade I/II* listed buildings, Grade I/II* registered parks/gardens, World Heritage Sites)

keyParagraphs.policyText: Where a proposed development will lead to substantial harm to (or total loss of significance of) a designated heritage asset, local planning authorities should refuse consent, unless it can be demonstrated that the substantial harm or total loss is necessary to achieve substantial public benefits that outweigh that harm or loss, or all of the following apply...

exception2_allMustApply: Nature of asset prevents all reasonable uses of site
No viable use of asset itself can be found in medium term through appropriate marketing
Conservation by grant-funding or charitable/public ownership demonstrably not possible
Harm/loss outweighed by benefit of bringing site back into use

keyParagraphs.policyText: Where a development proposal will lead to less than substantial harm to the significance of a designated heritage asset, this harm should be weighed against the public benefits of the proposal including, where appropriate, securing its optimum viable use.

keyConcepts.concept: Certificate of Lawfulness of Proposed Works (CLPW)
keyConcepts.description: Mechanism for obtaining certainty that LBC is not required
keyConcepts.procedure: Application to LPA for certificate confirming proposed works do not require LBC
keyConcepts.validity: 10 years (longer than LBC which is typically 3 years)
limitations: Does not remove need for planning permission

keyConcepts.guidancePrinciple: LBC required when works affect character as building of special architectural or historic interest
factors: Impact on historic fabric and materials
Impact on plan form and spatial arrangement
Impact on setting and curtilage structures

keyConcepts.principle: Pre-1948 buildings/structures within curtilage of listed building are treated as part of listed building
keyConcepts.legislativeSource: Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, Section 1(5)
keyConcepts.requiresAssessment: Whether structure is within curtilage (see HEAN 10)

technicalGuidance.guidanceDocument: Historic England Advice Note 2: Making Changes to Heritage Assets

keyConcepts.principle: Repair (like-for-like) may not require LBC; alteration affecting character does require LBC
keyConcepts.guidance: Maintenance using same materials, construction method, and design typically does not require LBC

keyConcepts.principle: Restoration of listed building requires alteration, needs LBC if affects character

technicalGuidance.purpose: Guide to assessing and describing significance of heritage assets
technicalGuidance.applicationRequirement: Proportionate statement of significance required with LBC applications (NPPF para 207)

technicalGuidance.purpose: Government guidance on implementing NPPF heritage policies

keyGuidance.guidance: Value of heritage asset to this and future generations because of its heritage interest (archaeological, architectural, artistic or historic)
Surroundings in which a heritage asset is experienced. Elements can make positive, neutral or negative contribution to significance.
Anything that delivers economic, social or environmental objectives described in the NPPF. Not limited to public access; includes heritage benefits, better use of site, economic growth.

preApplicationAdvice.benefit: Can save time and money; allows applicant to refine proposals

statutoryRequirements.requirement: Heritage assets assessed using appropriate expertise
statutoryRequirements.detail: Where necessary, use qualified heritage professionals

supportingDocuments.when: Required for certain applications (check with LPA)

requirements: Existing and proposed elevations
Floor plans
Site location plan
Block plan

supportingDocuments.purpose: Show existing condition, context, details affected by proposal

Works for alteration or extension of Grade I or II* listed building which would affect character

societies: Society for Protection of Ancient Buildings

postDecision.displayRequirement: Notice of consent may be required to be displayed on site

appeals.appealTo: Planning Inspectorate (on behalf of Secretary of State)

civilRemedies.purpose: Prevent unauthorized works or continuing breach

significance.definition: The value of a heritage asset to this and future generations because of its heritage interest. That interest may be archaeological, architectural, artistic or historic.
significance.assessment: Assessed by understanding special interest of asset and what contributes to it

setting.definition: The surroundings in which a heritage asset is experienced. Its extent is not fixed and may change as the asset and its surroundings evolve.
setting.note: Elements of setting may make positive, negative, or neutral contribution to significance

conservation.definition: The process of maintaining and managing change to a heritage asset in a way that sustains and, where appropriate, enhances its significance.

substantialHarm.definition: No statutory definition; assessed on case-by-case basis
substantialHarm.caselaw: High bar; not simply considerable, serious, or significant harm (Bedford case)
substantialHarm.guidance: Likely to arise where proposal would seriously affect attributes conveying significance

publicBenefits.definition: Anything that delivers economic, social or environmental objectives as described in the NPPF
includes: Heritage benefits (e.g. securing optimum viable use)

curtilage.definition: Land attached to and serving the listed building
curtilage.significance: Pre-1948 buildings/structures within curtilage are treated as part of listed building
curtilage.assessment: Complex legal question; see Historic England Advice Note 10
